content: The "Regulatory Right-to-Know Act of 1997" aims to promote public awareness of the costs and benefits of Federal regulatory programs, ensure government accountability for their growth, and encourage open communication among Federal agencies, the public, the President, and Congress regarding regulatory priorities. The "Regulatory Right-to-Know Act of 1997" defines an agency as any executive department, military department, Government corporation, or independent regulatory agency, excluding specific entities. It also defines benefit as the reasonably. The "Regulatory Right-to-Know Act of 1997" defines benefit as the significant favorable effects expected from a rule, and cost as the significant adverse effects expected from a rule. A program element is a rule or related set of rules, and a rule is defined as in section 551(4) of title 5, United States Code, excluding certain administrative actions. The "Regulatory Right-to-Know Act of 1997" defines benefit and cost of a rule as significant effects. A rule is defined as in section 551(4) of title 5, United States Code, excluding certain administrative actions. Rules exempted include those related to military or foreign affairs functions, and agency organization, management, or personnel. The "Regulatory Right-to-Know Act of 1997" defines benefit and cost of a rule as significant effects, excluding certain administrative actions. Rules exempted include those related to military or foreign affairs functions, and agency organization, management, or personnel. SEC. 4. ACCOUNTING STATEMENT. The President, through the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, is responsible for implementing and administering the Regulatory Right-to-Know Act of 1997. An accounting statement estimating costs and benefits of Federal regulatory programs must be submitted to Congress every two years starting in January 2000. The statement covers costs and benefits for the 5 fiscal years preceding October 1 of the year it is submitted. The President must provide notice and opportunity for comment for each accounting statement, with the first statement proposed no later than 1 year after the enactment of the Act. The statement should project costs and benefits for the next 10 fiscal years, with the option to revise previous estimates. The accounting statement must cover each fiscal year starting from 1997 and estimate the costs of Federal regulatory programs, including private sector costs. The President must provide notice and opportunity for comment on each statement, with the first one proposed within a year of the Act's enactment. The accounting statement must estimate costs and benefits of Federal regulatory programs, including private sector costs, federal sector administrative costs, federal sector compliance costs, state and local government administrative costs, and state and local government compliance costs. Estimates of benefits should include quantitative and qualitative measures, based on sound scientific practices, and present the most plausible level of risk. The accounting statement should estimate costs and benefits of Federal regulatory programs, including private sector costs, federal sector administrative costs, and state and local government compliance costs. It should also present the most plausible level of risk with a reasonable degree of scientific certainty. SEC. 5. ASSOCIATED REPORT TO CONGRESS. In each year after the President submits an accounting statement, a report must be submitted to Congress containing analyses of impacts, identification of overlaps in regulatory programs, and recommendations for reform. The report will include analyses of the cumulative impact of Federal regulatory programs. The President must submit a report to Congress each year containing analyses of impacts, identification of overlaps in regulatory programs, and recommendations for reform. The report will include a summary of independent analyses of impacts and factors to be considered such as the ability of State and local governments to provide essential services, small businesses, productivity, wages, economic growth, technological innovation, consumer prices, and other relevant factors. The President's annual report to Congress includes analyses of impacts, identification of regulatory program overlaps, and recommendations for reform. This report must contain the President's recommendations for reform or elimination of inefficient federal regulatory programs, as well as a summary of recommendations from commenters on the same. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Council of Economic Advisers, will provide guidance to agencies on standardizing measures of costs and benefits in accounting statements. This includes estimating costs and benefits of regulatory programs and standardizing the format of accounting statements. The Director will review agency submissions for consistency with this guidance. The Director of the Congressional Budget Office will make recommendations to the President for improving accounting statements and associated reports, including suggestions on detail, accuracy, and quality of analysis.
